meeting_annotations.speaker: Barbara Bendlin
meeting_annotations.transcript: what what does that bring to mind with regard to your own expertise or what's needed in the field.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Barbara Bendlin
meeting_annotations.transcript: All right, would anyone like to start by sharing what uh what comes to mind when thinking about these questions?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nandita Garud
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, I was looking at this phrase in the question, are there multiomics approaches that are that can be used beyond correlation, specifically beyond correlation to better leverage the massive data collection efforts. And uh, to me what comes to mind is models

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nandita Garud
meeting_annotations.transcript: of underlying processes that can generate the patterns that we see in the data. And I think what would be a really interesting uh future direction for the field would be to create generative models that can make predictions across data types. Uh, even within a given data type, it's hard to make predictions that fit multiple summary statistics. For example, you take genetic data, you predict one thing, but you fail to predict the other. So, um, the simpler the model, the better, uh, and often that's where modeling efforts start with, but uh clearly with simpler models you miss some of the subtler details.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Cologna
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think I can add something. One which is that when we're using like one data set, I think often or even multiple data sets, I think often times the data is underutilized.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Cologna
meeting_annotations.transcript: So, I know in my lab if we do like pathway analysis, right, of differential molecules, like we pick one and that's all we work on. So, um, I think this maybe also ties into the later comment about how should data be shared, um, and and made available to the community, but I think, you know, can maybe kind of piggy backing on Nandita's comment about making models, um, one I think is there a way that we can think about using the data more effectively. Um, and then I think there's another element which is what about missing data? So unannotation, um, or unassignable uh signals. I think maybe I just posed more questions and no answers, but nonetheless those are my thoughts.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Zongqi Xia
meeting_annotations.transcript: Another way to think about uh beyond correlation is uh having uh temporal component. Obviously genetic post genetics comes first, but there are other other dynamic process that we can look for particularly in chronic neurological diseases that take years to develop.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yanjiao Zhou
meeting_annotations.transcript: I I don't know if we we we mentioned this point. Um, so, you know, when we have several data sites, right? I guess it depends on the data type how how you design the study.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yang-Yu Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Temporal data, I think this this really depends on the informativeness of the temporal data. Uh, I can give you an example, if you look at the microbial composition over time, if the the uh the composition just fluctuate around a particular steady state, then this type of time series data is not very useful for us to infer causation because you're basically just looking at fluctuations. So you have to introduce very crazy perturbations, uh which very likely will uh raise ethical concerns for for humans. So, um, what I want to say is that uh temporal data is great, but the temporality should really help us infer the causation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Zongqi Xia
meeting_annotations.transcript: I I would say though that uh that that's the noise that we see um over time surely is a concern not just for microbiome data or any omic data.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Zongqi Xia
meeting_annotations.transcript: for example, imaging data, neuroimaging data is another uh example. However, if there is a large signal that we can see with or without some perturbation, and perturbation could be the disease onset that's happening in the natural environment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Zongqi Xia
meeting_annotations.transcript: at some point disease begins and or for example when people get exposure, uh the exposure could be antibiotics as as as as as a large perturbation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Zongqi Xia
meeting_annotations.transcript: um perturb perturbation and then you have some outcome to measurable outcome then if you're more likely to pick up a larger signal.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Zongqi Xia
